values.alignmentText: Generally high environmental quality outside dense urban cores; extensive protected landscapes and coastline.
Rising precipitation and storm intensity; coastal flooding risk; less extreme heat than continental Europe.
Oceanic—cool summers, mild winters, frequent rain/overcast; long summer daylight, short winter days.
Scenic but cool-water beaches; swimmable mostly for cold‑tolerant; great walks year‑round.
Roughly warmest Jul–Sep; otherwise chilly; wetsuits common.
Cliffs, peninsulas, lakelands, low mountains; many day/weekend trips.
Generally good; occasional winter particulate spikes (solid‑fuel heating) in some areas.
Low seismic risk; Atlantic storms possible; robust building standards.
EU norms for leave and hours; team culture varies.
Legal max 48; typical around 39–40 in many sectors.
At least 4 weeks annually (plus public holidays).
Tech often 23–25+ days, varies by employer.
Verify current national rate and any 2025 updates.
.NET / Ruby / Game dev ranges; senior vs. mid; Dublin highest.
Good in finance/consulting/enterprise (Dublin hub).
Smaller market; present in startups/SMEs; confirm demand.
Small ecosystem; mix of indie, middleware, services.
[Keywords Studios](https://www.keywordsstudios.com) (HQ Dublin), [Vela Games](https://velagames.com) (Dublin), [WarDucks](https://warducks.com) (AR/VR); plus indies.
[Imirt — Irish Game Makers](https://www.imirt.ie) (national association/network).
Dublin fast and pricey; Cork/Galway slower with trade‑offs on roles.
Hybrid common post‑pandemic; co‑working widely available.
Common for ICT roles via Critical Skills; reliable processes.
Low unemployment; GDP volatile due to multinationals; high cost of living.
Friendly, community‑oriented culture; vibrant music and pub life; strong literary/history scene.
English dominant; Irish is co‑official; high English proficiency.
Significant liberal shifts (e.g., marriage equality, reproductive rights) alongside some conservative currents.
Niche in discourse; mainstream politics centrist/center‑left/right mix.
Secularization advanced; Church influence diminished but present in schools.
Generally moderate‑liberal; sex‑ed improving; verify local norms.
Broad legal protections; social acceptance high in cities.
Welcoming to newcomers; strong clubs/associations; expat communities in cities.
Safe cities; parks/playgrounds common; weather limits outdoor time some days.
Not legally recognized; social acceptance niche and discreet; assess city subcultures.
Balanced; extracurriculars common; independence encouraged; verify school‑home load.
Good playgrounds, libraries, family‑friendly cafes; breastfeeding generally accepted.
English‑medium public schools; many with Catholic patronage; limited international schools; Irish taught.
Increasingly egalitarian; traditional norms persist in pockets.
Visible in urban areas; acceptance growing.
Strong legal protections; parental leave improving; confirm details.
Broadly flexible; safety relatively high.
Evolving; caregiving more normalized.
Hiking, GAA sports, soccer, cycling, music, sea‑swimming.
Active scenes in cities; FLGS and clubs; cons like [Gaelcon](https://gaelcon.com) / [Warpcon](https://warpcon.ie).
Strong live music/pub culture; festivals year‑round.
Active tech/game dev, parenting, LGBTQ+ groups; poly communities exist but low‑profile.
Abundant day trips by rail/bus/car from major cities.
Parliamentary republic; PR‑STV voting; multiparty coalition governance common.
Generally secular governance; residual church influence in education/health.
EU standards; unions present; termination processes regulated; non‑competes limited/enforceability varies.
Market‑friendly with social supports; strong MNC presence.
Public system with long queues for some services; many carry private insurance.
Private insurance often required; access to public services depends on residency status—verify specifics.
Subsidies expanding (National Childcare Scheme); availability varies by city.
Supports for families; verify benefits by status and income.
Low; independent media/judiciary; EU member checks.
Open economy; corporate tax reforms ongoing per OECD.
Strong outcomes; English instruction; higher‑ed quality; fees vary for non‑EU.
High political and economic stability; protest risk low‑moderate.
Low systemic propaganda; normal political messaging.
Focus on economy, services, housing; standard partisan frames.
Robust anti‑discrimination; LGBTQ+ legal recognition; reproductive rights.
Moderate; varies with housing/health outcomes.
Low by EU standards; transparency relatively strong.
More administrative/planning than overt; enforcement present.
Tight in Dublin; new supply improving; tenant protections exist; high rents.
Good in Dublin (bus, Luas, DART); limited intercity/regional frequencies; cars common outside cities.
Fast broadband in cities; widespread contactless; decent e‑gov; reliable grid.
Generally safe; petty crime in city cores; rare unrest episodes.
Open market economy with EU social protections.
State pension based on PRSI contributions over years; consider private pensions; US‑Ireland totalization agreement may help—verify.
PAYE with USC and PRSI; yearly self‑assessment if needed; credits for couples.
Progressive bands; mid‑to‑high effective rates when including USC/PRSI—model scenarios.
PPSN typically needed to open accounts; major banks plus fintechs; contactless ubiquitous.
Housing/childcare expensive in Dublin; groceries/utilities moderate EU‑level—verify local indices.
Critical Skills Employment Permit (CSEP), General Employment Permit (GEP), intra‑company transfer, student, family routes; Startup programmes via Enterprise Ireland.
Generally positive; high presence of US companies; straightforward processes.
Enterprise Ireland/LEO supports, New Frontiers, Imirt network; publishers/services in Dublin.
Stamps (1/1G/4 etc.); CSEP can lead to Stamp 4 after a period; GEP longer path.
Naturalisation typically after ~5 years of reckonable residence (with continuity requirements); dual citizenship allowed.
Partner work authorization often available (e.g., Stamp 1G with CSEP spouse); confirm current policy.
Processing times vary by route; expect weeks to months; fees apply.
Track tax residency days; keep GNIB/IRP renewals current; maintain health insurance as required.

cityShortlist.reason: Deepest tech/game ecosystem; Azure presence; best transit; highest costs.
Slower pace, good amenities and schools; growing tech; better affordability than Dublin.
Creative vibe, family-friendly, access to nature; smaller job market; consider remote/hybrid.

risksAndMitigations.mitigation: Expand search radius; consider Cork/Galway; engage relocation agents; time move with lease cycle.
Maintain private insurance; choose area with GP availability; plan for private clinics.
Apply early; target neighborhoods with multiple providers; leverage subsidies.

openQuestions: What are the current (2025) minimum wage and tax band thresholds?
Which neighborhoods balance walkability, school ethos (ET/non-denominational), and rent in each target city?
Which grants/incubators are most suitable for an indie game studio this year (EI/LEO/New Frontiers timing)?
What are current processing times and spouse work authorization details for CSEP/GEP?

executiveSummary.topPositives: English-first, stable EU democracy, mild climate, friendly culture, strong tech presence (Dublin), Azure region locally, good nature access.
executiveSummary.keyConcerns: High housing and childcare costs (esp. Dublin), healthcare wait times, rainy/overcast weather, smaller Ruby and game-dev job markets.
executiveSummary.unknownsToResearch: Current minimum wage and tax brackets, childcare subsidies in target cities, game-dev grants timeline and eligibility, permit processing times.
executiveSummary.bottomLine: Good cultural/political fit and language; quality-of-life balanced by cost and healthcare access. Worth a scouting trip focused on Dublin/Cork/Galway.
